sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Handwritten letter from Eugen d'Albert to Schenker, dated July 2, 1894
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: Eugen d'Albert thanks Schenker for a recommendation of his work. Things being difficult, he would have had to give up composing had he not also played the piano. He announces completion of his next opera.

tei:div.tei:p: Verzeihen Sie mein langes Schweigen! Sofort nach Empfang Ihrer liebenswürdigen ZeilenNo items of correspondence from Schenker to d’Albert are known to survive. sandte ich einen Clavierauszug meines „Rubin“Rubin, musical fairytale, libretto by d’Albert after F. Hebbel, first performed in Karlsruhe, October 12, 1893. an Dr. Löwe u. habe ihm selbst soeben ausführlich geschrieben.

Hoffen wir, dass etwas daraus wird! Ihnen danke ich aber herzlichst für die Empfehlung meines Werkes, – ein solcher Freundschaftsbeweis ist leider gar selten. Sie haben mich damit sehr glücklich gemacht!Schenker had sent d’Albert his article Anton Rubinstein, Neue Revue, vol. 5, No. 18 (April 18, 1894), 566–67, in which he remarked: “Like Rubinstein, a younger [composer], Eugen d’Albert, suffers equally harshly from having had belief in his genius as a performer impressed upon the public. […] It was a happy time when every composer could be his own virtuoso, and every virtuoso his own composer.”

Den deutschen Operncomponisten wird es in der That sauer genug gemacht; wenn ich nicht daneben Klavier spielte (was bis lange nicht so am Herzen liegt!) müsste
ich das Komponieren an den Nagel hängen.

tei:postscript.tei:p:
NB. Soeben habe ich eine neue Oper in 3 Akten „Ghismonda“Ghismonda, opera, libretto by d’Albert after K. Immermann, first performed in Dresden, November 28, 1895. vollendet. – – Coswig i/Sa.
2 Juli 1894.

tei:div.tei:p: Forgive me my long silence! Immediately after receiving your kind message I sent a piano reduction of my Rubin to Dr. Loewe and have myself written to him in as much detail.

Let us hope that something will come of it! But I thank you most cordially for the recommendation of my work – such proof of friendship is sadly rare indeed. You have made me a very happy man with that!

In fact, things are made very tough for the German opera composer. Had I not played the piano as well (which for long now has not been so dear to my heart!) I would have had
to give up on composing.

tei:postscript.tei:p:
NB. I have just completed a new opera in three acts, Ghismonda. – – Coswig in Saxony
July 2, 1894
